''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village.Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village.Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''BLOOMER GIRL,'' the Cotton Blossom Musicals revival of the 1944 musical. Set during the Civil War, the musical follows Dolly Bloomer, a character based on Amelia Bloomer, an early feminist and publisher of abolitionist material, and her fictitious niece, whose father is a prominent manufacturer of hoop skirts. Together the women try to eradicate the wearing of hoop skirts in favor of the much less confining bloomers. Thursdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m. and Sundays at 3 p.m. through Sept. 24 at the Theater at St. Clement's, 423 West 46th Street, Clinton. Tickets: $25; $15 for the elderly; $10 for students; Thursdays, pay what you can. Reservations: (212) 246-7277, extension 32.

''HANSEL AND GRETEL,'' presented for the marionette stage by Puppetworks and its artistic director, Nicolas Coppola. Saturdays and Sundays at 12:30 and 2:30 p.m. through Dec. 17 at Puppetworks-Park Slope, 338 Sixth Avenue, at Fourth Street, Brooklyn. For children 4 and older. Tickets: $7; $6 for children; $4.50 for groups of 20 or more. Reservations required. Information: (718) 965-3391.

HENSON INTERNATIONAL FESTIVAL OF PUPPET THEATRER. Batoto Yetu, a Harlem-based children's puppet troupe, in a program featuring drumming and dancing called ''The Mukishi.'' New Victory Theater, 330 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, tonight at 7, tomorrow at 2 and 7 p.m. and Sunday at noon and 5 p.m. ''Sleeping Beauty'' by the Paul Mesner Puppets, a troupe from Kansas City. Joseph Papp Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, tomorrow and Sunday at 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. Prasanna Rao, an artist from India, performing hand shadowgraphy in a double-bill with Teatro Hugo and Ines from Brazil, performing ''Short Stories,'' a combination of dance, mime and puppetry. Public Theater, tonight at 7, tomorrow at 2 and 7 p.m. and Sunday at noon and 5 p.m. Information: New Victory, (212) 564-4222; Public Theater, (212) 260-2400.
Events

''THE ADVENTURES OF ROCKY AND BULLWINKLE AND FRIENDS,'' selections from works by the television animator Jay Ward, through Sunday at the Museum of Television and Radio, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. Screenings are today, Saturday and Sundays at 12:15 p.m. and today at 7 p.m. Episodes include ''Wossamotta U,'' where Bullwinkle wins a football scholarship and Boris tries to fix the big game. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; until 8 p.m. on Thursdays; until 9 p.m. on Fridays (theater only). Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; ages 13 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

''CENTRAL PARK CONSERVANCY FISHING JAMBOREE AT THE HARLEM MEER,'' a catch-and-release fishing contest for ages 5 to 12, tomorrow from 11 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center at the Harlem Meer, Central Park at 110th Street, near Fifth Avenue. Fourteen stations will be set up surrounding the Meer for fishing, with rods and bait supplied. Art activities, storytelling and music will run simultaneously. Free. Registration required: (212) 860-1370.

''DAN AND CONRAD'S FAMILY VARIETY SHOW,'' Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53rd Street, Manhattan. This program of ventriloquism, comedy, magic and audience participation is intended for children 6 years and older. Admission is free. Information: (212) 621-0636.

LYDIA ADAMS DAVIS, tomorrow and Sunday at 10:30 and noon at the Mazur Theater, 555 East 90th Street, Manhattan. A singer, songwriter and guitarist, Ms. Davis uses music and puppets in her interactive show. Admission: $7; $6 groups of 10 or more. Information: (212) 369-8890, extension 159.

''FALL FAMILY FESTIVAL 2000: A COMMUNITY CELEBRATION,'' a final fling for summer on Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m., at the Central Queens Y, 67-09 108th Street, Forest Hills. Includes pony rides, face painting, bingo, a ballet workshop, cake decorating, an indoor play gym, a story hour, ceramics workshop, creative arts demonstrations and other activities. Free. Information: (718) 268-5011.

''GO FISH!'' A day of fishing, art projects and music sponsored by Battery Park City Parks Conservancy, tomorrow from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. in Wagner Park, entrance at Battery Place and West Side Highway, Lower Manhattan. Catch-and-release fishing (rods and bait will be provided free, but anglers are encouraged to bring their own) will take place from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Art projects relating to the Hudson River's marine life will take place from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m., after which the musical group Sirius Coyote will perform. Free. Information: (212) 267-9700.

''HARVEST FAIR'' at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights, tomorrow from 10:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. In addition to city gardeners' contests for fruits and vegetables, there will be crafts and games for children. Admission: free with a can of food. Information: (718) 623-7241.

''HANS CHRISTIAN ANDERSEN: THE MAN AND HIS TALES,'' a program of stories at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, tomorrow at 3 p.m. with Randel McGee, storyteller. Recommended for children 6 and older. Admission is free. Information: (212) 621-0636.

''HOMEWORK ASSISTANCE PROGRAM,'' today at 6 p.m. at the Central Library, 89-11 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens. Orientation and registration for the after-school program held at the library on school-days to provide a safe, constructive place for young students until parents can pick them up at 6 p.m. Free. Information: (718) 990-0767.

''LIFE AND TIMES OF THE PORT.'' The American Museum of Natural History presents this walking tour for children that visits the New York Harbor's historic district, tomorrow from 10 a.m. to noon. This tour, recommended for children 11 to 13, will stop at the port where clipper ships, sailors and soup kitchens once thrived. and will look at the spirit of today's East River. Admission: $20. Reservations required: (212) 769-5200.

''OPEN HOUSE,'' Sunday from noon to 3 p.m. at the 92nd Street Y School of the Arts, at Lexington Avenue. Information about the Y's art, dance and music classes. Prospective students may tour the center, meet the faculty and take sample classes. Free. Information: (212) 996-1100.

''STORYTELLING IN THE GALLERIES: FROM THE OLD WORLD JEWISH RITUAL SILVER.'' Hara Person will tell tales of humor, tricksters and moral dilemmas in the old-world setting of this exhibition tomorrow at 4 p.m. at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Workshops are free with museum admission of $4; $2 for students and the elderly; free for children under 12. Information: (718) 638-5000.

''RESTORATION OF THE LITTLE RED LIGHTHOUSE.'' This trip to the Little Red Lighthouse on Sunday from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. is intended as a family outing (take a picnic lunch) along the Hudson River through Fort Washington Park. Roger Lang of the Landmark Conservancy, Scott Heyl of the National Historic Trust and a storyteller will give versions of the history of the lighthouse. Sponsored by the 92nd Street Y. Admission: $18; free for children under 12. Information: (212) 996-1100.
Exhibitions

''BABAR AND THE SUCCOTASH BIRD,'' featuring the first new Babar book in seven years, in the form of 18 original watercolors drawn by the author and illustrator Laurent de Brunhoff. Through Sept. 30. Mary Ryan Gallery, second floor, 24 West 57th Street, Manhattan. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Information: (212) 397-0669.

''AN ENGAGEMENT WITH FOLK ART; CYRIL I. NELSON'S GIFTS TO THE MUSEUM OF AMERICAN FOLK ART.'' Children's workshops are offered in conjunction with this show at the Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, on Sundays from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. through Dec. 17. This week's theme is ''Portrait of Me,'' exploring themes in the show with activities. Admission: free for the museum; $1 materials charge for workshops. Information: (212) 595-9533.

''FROM TENT TO TEMPLE: LIFE IN THE ANCIENT NEAR EAST,'' an interactive exhibition developed by the Jewish Children's Learning Lab, Center for Jewish History, Yeshiva University Museum, 15 West 16th Street, Chelsea, (212) 294-8330, showing the daily lives of people in biblical times, featuring 28 interactive learning stations. In more than 30 displays, the exhibition challenges children to solve problems the way their biblical ancestors did, building a miniature plow, grinding grain with stones, or even hunting game -- images of it, that is -- with bows and arrows ending in suction cups. Through Jan. 14. Hours: Mondays, Wednesdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Free with admission: $6; the elderly and ages 5 to 12, $4; under 5 and members, free.

''WILLIAM WEGMAN: CANES ECCLESIORUM,'' a photography exhibition on view at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights, through Oct. 22. Mr. Wegman, the photographer, filmmaker and painter, is best known for the comic photographs of his dogs doing contemporary humanlike things. Free. Information: (212) 316-7449.
